title: Secret Service Agent Who Threatened To Not Take A Bullet For Trump Is Not Being Fired

organizations.name: maintain political impartiality if confirmed as supreme court justice

text:
Secret Service Agent Who Threatened To Not Take A Bullet For Trump Is Not Being Fired "She has lost all credibility ..." by Charles Campbell  04pm   
A 23-year veteran of the Secret Service who implied that she would rather be incarcerated than take a bullet for President Donald Trump has been removed from her post but not fired, according to a report from Fox & friends. 
Kerry O’Grady, who was in charge of the Denver district of the Secret Service, was discovered to have written a social media comment voicing strong animosity towards Trump. 
“I struggle not to violate the Hatch Act. So I keep quiet and skirt the median. To do otherwise can be a criminal offense for those in my position. Despite the fact that I am expected to take a bullet for both sides,” O’Grady wrote in an old Facebook post.   Neil Gorsuch Vows To Maintain Political Impartiality If Confirmed As Supreme Court Justice 
“But this world has changed and I have changed. And I would take jail time over a bullet or an endorsements for what I believe to be a disaster to this country and the strong and amazing women and minorities who reside here. Hatch Act be damned. I am with Her,” she added. 
After O’Grady’s statements began to make national headlines, the Secret Service quickly place her on administrative leave. At the time, it was unknown whether she would be fired for her comments. 
The Washington Examiner reported that top officials at the Secret Service may be trying to shield O’Grady and place her in another government job, possibly at the Department of Homeland Security.   
However, agents within the service are still worried she will be allowed to serve out her time until she can retire with a pension, as the agency has done with other controversial officials in the past. 
O’Grady was removed from a retired Secret Service member association—The Association of Former Agents U.S. Secret Service. 
Her former job was also placed on a list of agency openings. 
O’Grady claims her opinions of the president wouldn’t have impacted her ability to execute her duties.
